sub_topic: Show that every group of order 20 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C20, the dihedral group D10, or the non-abelian group of order 20.
message_1: How many distinct isomorphism classes are possible for a group of order 20? Identify each class and give an example of a group in each class.
message_2:
There are five distinct isomorphism classes possible for a group of order 20. These classes are:

1. Cyclic group: A group is cyclic if it can be generated by a single element. In this case, the group is isomorphic to the additive group of integers modulo 20, denoted as Z_20 or C_20. An example of a group in this class is the set of integers modulo 20 under addition, {0, 1, 2, ..., 19}.

2. Direct product of two cyclic groups: The group can be represented as the direct product of two cyclic groups of orders 4 and 5, which are coprime. This group is isomorphic to Z_4 × Z_5 or C_4 × C_5. An example of a group in this class is the set of ordered pairs of integers modulo 4 and modulo 5 under component-wise addition, {(0,0), (0,1), ..., (3,4)}.

3. Dihedral group: The dihedral group of order 20, denoted as D_10 or D_20, is the group of symmetries of a regular decagon, including rotations and reflections. An example of a group in this class is the set of symmetries of a regular decagon.

4. Dicyclic group: The dicyclic group of order 20, denoted as Dic_10 or Dic_20, is a non-abelian group that is a generalization of the dihedral group. It can be defined by the presentation: ⟨a, b | a^10 = b^2 = e, b^(-1)ab = a^(-1)⟩. An example of a group in this class is the set of 20 elements generated by a and b satisfying the given relations.

5. Semidirect product of Z_5 and Z_4: The group can be represented as the semidirect product of Z_5 and Z_4, denoted as Z_5 ⋊ Z_4 or C_5 ⋊ C_4. This group is non-abelian and can be defined by the presentation: ⟨a, b | a^5 = b^4 = e, b^(-1)ab = a^3⟩. An example of a group in this class is the set of 20 elements generated by a and b satisfying the given relations.
